overview_of_class: The vortex of Latin literature and, arguably, "the classic of all Europe" (in T.S. Eliot's formulation) Vergil's Aeneid presents itself simultaneously as a poetic mirror of "everything" (the cosmos itself, the place of gods and humans in it) and a meditation on the burden of Rome (?of founding Rome, of being Roman, of opposing Rome). It argues that the world-city is the fulfillment of a divine, cosmic plan, that its hero's burden of administering violence in a savage world is justified by the reward his descendants will reap - of eternally administering an empire won by violence and still threatened by savagery. "Is it all worth it?" We will read and discuss extensive selections of Books 1, 2, 4, and 6 - which is to say, many of the most beautiful and unforgettable words composed in Latin, or any language - to see that our long burden of amo, amas, and amat-ing to greatness, at least, is indeed justified by the burden-reward this poem is.
